newsitem.title: UK: SOCCER-STUNNING SOLSKJAER SETS FERGUSON A TEASER.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-STUNNING SOLSKJAER SETS FERGUSON A TEASER.

text.p: Manchester United's fluent triumph over Tottenham on Sunday and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's two superb goals have presented manager Alex Ferguson with the happiest of problems.
"It's something of a nightmare for me to pick a team now," he admitted after his side's 2-0 win. "I've got so many good players for so many positions and the team has so many options.
"But Ole's goals means he picks himself."

Solskjaer's majestic double-strike took his tally to five goals from eight appearances for United and helped lift the defending champions to third in the league, four points behind arch-rivals and leaders Liverpool, who travel to Old Trafford on October 12.

Consider that four of those eight appearances have been as a substitute, and the 23-year-old Norwegian's record in front of goal looks all the more impressive, particularly at home, where he has yet to draw a blank.

"It's incredible, I can't believe it," said Solskjaer, who admitted he had not expected to break into the United first-team so soon after his 1.5 million pound ($2.34 million) close season signing from Norway's Molde FC. "To hear 55,000 people chanting my name was unbelievable."
Solskjaer's form has stunned even Ferguson, who signed him as an investment for the future rather than the present.

The Norwegian's five strikes from 363 minutes on the pitch puts him level in the goal-scoring stakes with Liverpool's Patrik Berger, the other young foreigner currently sending ripples through the premier league.
Like Solskjaer, Berger spent then first few games of the season on the sidelines at Anfield, waiting for a work visa and getting himself match fit.
Since coming on a second half substitute at Leicester a fortnight ago the powerful Czech forward has been unstoppable.
He scored two goals in that match, grabbed another two against Chelsea a week later and added a fifth against Finland's MyPa-47 in the Cup Winners' Cup in midweek.
Berger failed to find the net at the weekend but that did not stop Liverpool winning 2-1 at West Ham -- their sixth straight victory in all competitions.

Their winner on Sunday -- the 15th anniversary of the death of the club's legendary manager Bill Shankly -- was classic Liverpool, Michael Thomas rounding off a 15-pass move started by David James in the Liverpool goal.
"It's a lovely tribute to Shanks," current Liverpool manager Roy Evans said. "The way we are playing now is the way Shanks would have liked."
